qas.question: Which countries didn't want to go around the bail-out clause and have to shoulder the burden of backing the defaulters debts.

answers.text: financially stable eurozone states like Germany

qas.question: What do most see raising the debt celing as doing?

answers.text: discourage the crisis states to implement necessary reforms to regain their competitiveness

qas.question: What could keep the crisis states from trying to stand on their own?

answers.text: giving much more financial support to continuously cover the debt crisis or allow even higher budget deficits or debt levels

plausible_answers.text: financially stable eurozone states like Germany

qas.question: Which countries wanted to go around the bail-out clause and have to shoulder the burden of backing the defaulters debts?

plausible_answers.text: giving much more financial support to continuously cover the debt crisis or allow even higher budget deficits or debt levels

qas.question: What could keep the crisis states independent?

plausible_answers.text: discourage the crisis states to implement necessary reforms to regain their competitiveness

qas.question: What do most see lowering the debt celing as doing?
What contracts do not contain a no-bailout clause?

context: There is also a widespread view[vague][who?] that <a2_0><b4_0>giving much more financial support to continuously cover the debt crisis or allow even higher budget deficits or debt levels<b4_0/><a2_0/> would <a1_0><b5_0>discourage the crisis states to implement necessary reforms to regain their competitiveness<b5_0/><a1_0/>.[citation needed] There has also been a reluctance[citation needed] of <a0_0><b3_0>financially stable eurozone states like Germany<b3_0/><a0_0/>[citation needed] to further circumvent the no-bailout clause in the <b6_0>EU contracts<b6_0/> and to generally take on the burden of financing or guaranteeing the debts of financially unstable or defaulting eurozone countries.[citation needed]
